facts.text: Writ Petition No. 448 of 1974 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 448 of 1974. Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Petitioner is the karta of a Joint Hindu family running a shop named Popular Pharmacy in Ranchi for selling medicines and drugs.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is the karta of a Joint Hindu family and as such karta he runs a shop for selling medicines and drugs under the name of Popular Pharmacy in Ranchi.

facts.text: On 22nd April, 1974, at about 8 p.m. Vijoy Shankar accompanied by R. N. P. Dube went to the petitioner's shop and asked for certain medicines according to a prescription.

anchor.surface_text: On 22nd April, 1974, at about 8 p.m. one Vijoy Shankar accompanied by R. N. P. Dube, Executive Magistrate, went to the shop of the petitioner and asked for certain medicines according to a prescription made out by a House Surgeon of the Medical College, Ranchi.

facts.text: Petitioner asked Vijoy Shankar and R. N. P. Dube to come at 8.30 p.m. to supply the medicines.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, who was present at the shop, asked Vijoy Shanker and R. N. P. Dube to companye at 8.30 p.m. and stated that he would then be able to supply the medicines to them.

facts.text: At 8.30 p.m. on 22nd April 1974, petitioner supplied medicines including two ampoules of pethidine and one bottle of ether.

anchor.surface_text: Vijoy Shankar and Dube accordingly visited the shop again at 8.30 p.m. when the petitioner supplied most of the medicines mentioned in the prescription. Amongst the medicines so supplied were two ampoules of pathedine and one bottle of ether.

facts.text: Petitioner charged Rs. 3/- for two ampoules of pethidine against price of 90 paise per ampoule in current price list.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner charged for these two ampoules of pathedine Rs. 3/- as against the price of 90 paise per empoule shown in the current price list

facts.text: Petitioner charged Rs. 20/- for one bottle of ether containing 450 grms. against price of Rs. 6.85 in current price list.

anchor.surface_text: and for the bottle of ether, which companytained 450 grms., he charged Rs. 20/as against the price of Rs. 6.85 shown in the current price list.

facts.text: This was in contravention of paragraph 15(2) of the Drug Price Control Order, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: This was in companytravention of paragraph 15  2  of the Drug  Price Control  Order, 1970.

facts.text: Petitioner refused to issue cash memo for the two ampoules of pethidine and one bottle of ether though bound under paragraph 22 of Drug Price Control Order, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner also refused to issue cash memo in respect of the two ampoules of pathedine and one bottle of ether supplied by him, though he was bound to do so under paragraph 22 of the Drug  Price Control  Order, 1970.

facts.text: Petitioner gave false name Sailendra Kumar Gupta to Vijoy Shankar and R. N. P. Dube; real name is Satya Deo Prasad Gupta.

anchor.surface_text: When asked by Vijoy Shankar and R. N. P. Dube to give his name, the petitioner falsely and deliberately gave his name as Sailendra Kumar Gupta though his real name was Satya Deo Prasad Gupta.

facts.text: On 23rd April, 1974, representatives of Nao Nirman Samiti took petitioner out, garlanded with shoes, affixed placard, paraded in rickshaw.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on the following day, that is, 23rd April, 1974, a group of persons claiming to be representatives of a body known as Nao Nirman Samiti came to the petitioners shop, forcibly took him out and after placing a garland of shoes around his neck and affixing a placard displaying the slogan Main black marketeer hun.

facts.text: New Republic newspaper published photograph of petitioner being paraded on 27th April, 1974.

anchor.surface_text: The New Republic, a local newspaper, published in its issue dated 27th April, 1974, a photograph of the petitioner as he was being paraded in this procession.

facts.text: District Magistrate, Ranchi issued first detention order under section 3(2)(iii) MISA naming Sailendra Kumar Gupta.

anchor.surface_text: The District Magistrate, Ranchi thereafter issued an order of detention under section 3  2   iii  of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971 directing that Sailendra Kumar Gupta that being the name given by the petitioner to Vijoy Shankar and R. N. P. Dube at the time when they made purchases from him-should be detained

facts.text: First detention order cancelled because real name is Satya Deo Prasad Gupta.

anchor.surface_text: This order of detention had, however, to be cancelled since the real name of the petitioner was Satya Deo Prasad Gupta and number Sailendra Kumar Gupta as mentioned in the order of detention.

facts.text: District Magistrate issued second detention order dated 11th June, 1974 under section 3(2)(iii) MISA.

anchor.surface_text: The District Magistrate then issued another order dated 11th June, 1974 of detention under section 3 2  iii  of the Act on the ground that it was necessary to detain the petitioner

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on 11th July, 1974 pursuant to detention order; grounds served at arrest.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the order of detention the petitioner was arrested on 11th July, 1974 and at the time of his arrest, grounds of detention were served on him.

facts.text: Grounds of detention relate to incident of 22nd April 1974: overpricing and no cash memo.

anchor.surface_text: These grounds related to the incident of 22nd April, 1974 when the petitioner had sold two ampoules of pathedine and one bottle of ether at prices exceeding those shown in the current list of prices in companytravention of paragraph  15 2 of the Drug  Price Control  Order, 1970 and refused to issue cash memo

facts.text: District Magistrate reported detention to State Government immediately; approved within period under section 3(3).

anchor.surface_text: The District Magistrate, immediately after making the order of detention, reported the fact to the State Government and the order of detention was unproved by the State Government within the period prescribed by section 3, sub-section  3 .

facts.text: State Government placed case before Advisory Board on 9th August, 1974.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government thereafter placed the case of the petitioner before the Advisory Board on 9th August, 1974 as required by section 10.

facts.text: Petitioner's representation received by State Government on 16th August, 1974 and sent to Advisory Board.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, however, on 16th August, 1974 the representation of the petitioner was received and the State Government immediately sent it to the Advisory Board for its companysideration.

facts.text: Advisory Board made report dated 20th August, 1974 stating sufficient cause to detain petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: The Advisory Board, after companysidering the grounds of detention, the other material placed before it and the representation of the petitioner made a report dated 20th August, 1974 stating that in its opinion there was sufficient cause to detain the petitioner.

facts.text: State Government confirmed detention order on 15th November, 1974.

anchor.surface_text: we found that the order rejecting the representation of the petitioner and companyfirming the order of detention was made by the Government as late as 15th November, 1974

facts.text: Petition heard on 11th November, 1974 before Chandrachud J. and Bhagwati J., adjourned for records.

anchor.surface_text: When the petition originally came up for hearing before a Bench of this Court companysisting of Chandrachud, J, and one of us  Bhagwati, J.  on 11th November. 1974.

facts.text: Petition heard on 18th November, 1974; records perused showing confirmation on 15th Nov.

anchor.surface_text: The petition thereafter came up for hearing before us on 18th November. 1974. Mr, U. P. Singh on behalf of the Government of Bihar placed before us the record of the case and on perusing the record.

facts.text: Deputy Collector Ranchi affidavit sworn on 14th October, 1974 stated State considered representation before that date.

anchor.surface_text: This statement was made in the affidavit in reply which was sworn by the Deputy Collector, Ranchi on 14th October, 1974.

facts.text: Court found inordinate delay of about three months by State in considering representation received 16 Aug 1974.

anchor.surface_text: We have already referred to the original record of the case and that clearly shows that though the representation of the petitioner was received by the State Government on 16th August, 1974 ... the State Government slept over the matter for a period of about three months and companysidered the representation of the petitioner only on 15th November, 1974

facts.text: No explanation offered by State for delay in considering representation.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberexplanation for this inordinate delay offered by the State Government.

facts.text: Confirmation order made beyond three months from detention date of 11 July 1974 (after 11 Oct 1974).

anchor.surface_text: Here, in the present case, the petitioner was detained pursuant to the order of detention on 11th July, 1974 and the order companyfirming the detention should, therefore, have been passed at the latest on 11th October. 1974. But the State Government ... it was only on 15th November, 1,974 that it suddenly woke up to make the order of companyfirmation.

facts.text: Court held detention invalid due to delay in considering representation and late confirmation.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore. on this ground alone, the detention of the petitioner must be held to be invalid. ... the order of detention must be held to be invalid.

facts.text: Court directs petitioner set at liberty forthwith.

anchor.surface_text: We, accordingly, allow the petition and make the rule absolute and direct that the petitioner should be set at liberty forthwith.

issues.text: Whether there was inordinate delay on the part of the State Government in considering the representation of the detenu without satisfactory explanation, rendering the detention invalid

anchor.surface_text: There was obviously inordinate delay on the part of the State Government in companysidering the representation of the Petitioner. There is numberexplanation for this inordinate delay offered by the State Government. We asked Mr. U. P. Singh whether he was in a position on behalf of the State Government to offer an explanation for this apparently unreasonable delay, but he companfessed his inability to do so.

issues.text: Whether the confirmation of the detention order was made within three months from the date of detention as required by Article 22(4) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: the law is number well settled as a result of a decision of this Court in S. Roy v. The State of West Bengal 2  that on a proper interpretation of Art. 22, clause  4  of the Constitution, the confirmation of the detention with a view to companytinue it beyond a period of three months, on receipt of the opinion of the Advisory Board, must be within three months from the date of detention.

issues.text: Whether the State Government had failed to consider the representation of the petitioner and to make the order of confirmation within a reasonable time, rendering the detention invalid

anchor.surface_text: The only ground urged by Mr. D. P. Singh, learned companynsel appearing on behalf of the petitioner, against the validity of the detention was that the State Government had failed to companysider the representation of the petitioner and to make the order of companyfirmation within a reasonable time and the detention of the petitioner had, therefore. become invalid.

issues.text: Whether the Court has limited jurisdiction to enquire into the truth or falsity of the grounds of detention in preventive detention cases

anchor.surface_text: limited jurisdiction in cases of this kind to enquire into the truth or falsity of the grounds of detention

arguments.claim: State Government failed to consider the representation of the petitioner and to make the order of confirmation within a reasonable time making detention invalid

anchor.surface_text: The only ground urged by Mr. D. P. Singh, learned counsel appearing on behalf of the petitioner, against the validity of the detention was that the State Government had failed to consider the representation of the petitioner and to make the order of confirmation within a reasonable time and the detention

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ntation but also by putting off the companysideration till after the receipt of the opinion of the Advisory Board. As we have already observed there i

arguments.court_reasoning: Inordinate unexplained delay of three months in considering representation received 16 Aug 1974 until 15 Nov 1974 violates constitutional obligation per Jayanarayan Sukul precedent

arguments.claim: State Government fully rightly and sympathetically considered the petitioner's representation prior to 14 October 1974

anchor.surface_text: This statement was made in the affidavit in reply which was sworn by the Deputy Collector, Ranchi on 14th October, 1974. ... the State Government fully, rightly and sympathetically considered the petition of the petitioner.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: pathetically companysidered the representation of the petitioner prior to the date of the affidavit in reply, that is before 14th October, 1974, was p

arguments.court_reasoning: Original records show order rejecting representation and confirming detention made as late as 15 Nov 1974, rendering affidavit patently false

arguments.claim: Court has limited jurisdiction in preventive detention cases and cannot enquire into truth or falsity of grounds of detention

anchor.surface_text: limited jurisdiction in cases of this kind to enquire into the truth or falsity of the grounds of detention

arguments.claim: Inordinate delay by State in considering detenu's representation without explanation renders detention invalid

anchor.surface_text: There was obviously inordinate delay on the part of the State Government in considering the representation of the Petitioner. There is no explanation for this inordinate delay offered by the State Government.

arguments.court_reasoning: Delay of about three months from 16 Aug to 15 Nov with no explanation; applies Jayanarayan Sukul v State of West Bengal

arguments.claim: Confirmation of detention order must be within three months from date of detention per Art 22(4); late confirmation invalidates detention

anchor.surface_text: the law is now well settled as a result of a decision of this Court in S. Roy v. The State of West Bengal that on a proper interpretation of Art. 22, clause 4 of the Constitution, the confirmation of the detention ... must be within three months from the date of detention.

arguments.court_reasoning: Detention 11 Jul 1974 requires confirmation by 11 Oct 1974 but made 15 Nov 1974; applies S Roy v State of West Bengal

arguments.claim: Detention under section 3(2)(iii) MISA necessary to prevent petitioner from acting prejudicial to maintenance of supplies and services by overpricing drugs and refusing cash memos

anchor.surface_text: These grounds related to the incident of 22nd April, 1974 when the petitioner had sold two ampoules of pethidine and one bottle of ether at prices exceeding those shown in the current list of prices in contravention of paragraph 15(2) of the Drug Price Control Order, 1970 and refused to issue cash memo

arguments.court_reasoning: Court exercises limited jurisdiction and does not enquire into merits or truth of grounds

holdings.text: it would not be open to this Court in the exercise of its limited jurisdiction in cases of this kind to enquire into the truth or falsity of the grounds of detention

anchor.surface_text: limited jurisdiction in cases of this kind to enquire into the truth or falsity of the grounds of detention. When the petition originally came up for hearing before a Bench of this Court consisting of Chandrachud, J, and one of us (Bhagwati, J.) on 11th November. 1974.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preventive detention cases limit court to procedural infirmities, not merits of subjective satisfaction or truth of grounds

holdings.text: where there is inordinate delay on the part of the State Government in considering the representation of a detenu and no satisfactory explanation is offered by the State Government for such delay, the constitutional obligation is violated and the detention is rendered invalid

anchor.surface_text: It is not well settled by the decision of a Bench of five Judges of this Court in Jayanarayan Sukul v. State of West Bengal 2 that where there is inordinate delay on the part of the State Government in considering the representation of a detenu and no satisfactory explanation is offered by the State Government for such delay, the constitutional obligation is violated and the detention is rendered invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Jayanarayan Sukul; unexplained delay of three months from receipt on 16 Aug 1974 to consideration on 15 Nov 1974

holdings.text: on this ground alone, the detention of the petitioner must be held to be invalid

anchor.surface_text: Therefore. on this ground alone, the detention of the petitioner must be held to be invalid. There is also another ground which must result in invalidation of the detention of the petitioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies doctrine of invalidity due to inordinate unexplained delay in considering representation

holdings.text: on a proper interpretation of Art. 22, clause 4 of the Constitution, the confirmation of the detention with a view to continue it beyond a period of three months, on receipt of the opinion of the Advisory Board, must be within three months from the date of detention

anchor.surface_text: Art. 22, clause 4 of the Constitution, the confirmation of the detention with a view to continue it beyond a period of three months, on receipt of the opinion of the Advisory Board, must be within three months from the date of detention. The confirmation of the detention must, therefore. follow within three months from the date of detention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows S. Roy v. State of West Bengal; confirmation required by 11 Oct 1974 but made 15 Nov 1974

holdings.text: the order of detention must be held to be invalid

anchor.surface_text: there is, therefore, no escape from the conclusion that the order of detention must be held to be invalid. We may point out that the decision of this Court in D. S. Roy v. The State of West Bengal 2 was given as far back as 7th December, 1971

holdings.reasoning_summary: Confirmation beyond constitutional three-month limit from 11 Jul 1974 detention date

holdings.text: We are thus left with no choice but to hold the detention of the petitioner invalid
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of delay in representation consideration and late confirmation

holdings.text: direct that the petitioner should be set at liberty forthwith

anchor.surface_text: We, accordingly, allow the petition and make the rule absolute and direct that the petitioner should be set at liberty forthwith.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consequence of holding detention invalid under Article 32

precedents.citation: Dwarika Prasad Sahu V. State of Bihar, W. P. 346 of 1974, decided on 12-11-1974.

anchor.surface_text: Rs. 6.85 shown in the current price list. This Dwarika Prasad Sahu V. State of Bihar, W. P. 346 of 1974, decided on 12-11-1974. was in contravention of paragraph 15  2  of the Drug  Price Control  Order, 1970.

precedents.case_name: Dwarika Prasad Sahu v. State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: economic offenders are a menace to the society and the Court would naturally be loath to interfere with an order of detention which is calculated to put an economic offender out of action by way of social defence

precedents.citation: Jayanarayan Sukul v. State of West Bengal 2

anchor.surface_text: It is number well settled by the decision of a Bench of five Judges of this Court in Jayanarayan Sukul v. State of West Bengal 2  that where there is inordinate delay on the part of the State Government in companysidering the representation of a detenu and numbersatisfactory explanation is offered by the State Government for such delay, the companystitutional obligation is violated and the detention is rendered invalid.

precedents.case_name: Jayanarayan Sukul v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: where there is inordinate delay on the part of the State Government in considering the representation of a detenu and no satisfactory explanation is offered by the State Government for such delay, the constitutional obligation is violated and the detention is rendered invalid
precedents.cited_holding: In the present case, the State of West Bengal is guilty of infraction of the constitutional provision not only by inordinate delay of the consideration of the representation but also by putting off the consideration till after the receipt of the opinion of the Advisory Board.

precedents.citation: S. Roy v. The State of West Bengal 2

anchor.surface_text: The law is number well settled as a result of a decision of this Court in S. Roy v. The State of West Bengal 2  that on a proper interpretation of Art. 22, clause  4  of the Constitution, the companyfirmation of the detention with a view to companytinue it beyond a period of three months, on receipt of the opinion of the Advisory Board, must be within three months from the date of detention.

precedents.case_name: S. Roy v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: on a proper interpretation of Art. 22 clause 4 of the Constitution, the confirmation of the detention with a view to continue it beyond a period of three months, on receipt of the opinion of the Advisory Board, must be within three months from the date of detention

precedents.citation: D. S. Roy v. The State of West Bengal 2 3 S.C.R. 225. A. 1. R. 1972 S. C. 1924. 7th December, 1971

anchor.surface_text: We may point out that the decision of this Court in D. S. Roy v. The State of West Bengal 2  was given as far back as  1  1970 3 S.C.R. 225. A. 1. R. 1972 S. C. 1924. 7th December, 1971 and Yet the State Government in the present case acted in contravention of the constitutional mandate enunciated and explained in that decision.

precedents.case_name: D. S. Roy v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: the confirmation of the detention must follow within three months from the date of detention

anchor.surface_text: It is not well settled by the decision of a Bench of five Judges of this Court in Jayanarayan Sukul v. State of West Bengal 2 that where there is inordinate delay on the part of the State Government in considering the representation of a detenu and no satisfactory explanation is offered by the State Government for such delay, the constitutional obligation is violated and the detention is rendered invalid.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore. on this ground alone, the detention of the petitioner must be held to be invalid. There is also another ground which must result in invalidation of the detention of the petitioner.
We, accordingly, allow the petition and make the rule absolute and direct that the petitioner should be set at liberty forthwith.

Art. 22, clause 4 of the Constitution, the confirmation of the detention with a view to continue it beyond a period of three months, on receipt of the opinion of the Advisory Board, must be within three months from the date of detention. The confirmation of the detention must, therefore. follow within three months from the date of detention.
We, accordingly, allow the petition and make the rule absolute and direct that the petitioner should be set at liberty forthwith.

there is, therefore, no escape from the conclusion that the order of detention must be held to be invalid. We may point out that the decision of this Court in D. S. Roy v. The State of West Bengal 2 was given as far back as 7th December, 1971
We, accordingly, allow the petition and make the rule absolute and direct that the petitioner should be set at liberty forthwith.
